quoteFirst: The lethargy of afternoon held the thoroughfare in its grip. Occasionally a tradesman’s cart would rattle round the corner, and from time to time cats appeared, stalking purposefully among the evergreens. But at
quoteLast: a girl ran up the steps of Number Eighteen and rang the bell.
title: Leave it to Psmith
author: Wodehouse, P. G. (Pelham Grenville), 1881-1975

quoteFirst: To its right front was the Howitzer battery, while the three field batteries came into action to the north-east of Headquarter Hill, at a range of 2,000 yards. Their first target was Magersfontein Hill, on which they opened about
quoteLast: , as soon as they could see to lay their guns, but the officers, soon realising that the Boers were holding, not the kopje itself, but trenches cut at its foot, reduced their range to 1,700 yards, with the result that the volume of the enemy's fire sensibly decreased.
title:
History of the War in South Africa 1899-1902 v. 1 (of 4)
Compiled by Direction of His Majesty's Government
author: Great Britain. War Office; Maurice, John Frederick, 1841-1912 [Compiler]

quoteFirst: “How can I tell you? it was perfection, _vi bisognava vederla_,” was the enthusiastic reply. “Stay,” he continued, glancing at the clock, which now only wanted
quoteLast: ; “I have an idea; there is yet time, but you must never relate that you have beheld it. Here, follow me;” and drawing out a key, he unlocked a door leading into a small apartment, comfortably though simply furnished, and fitted up with bookshelves somewhat after the fashion of an English study.
title: Lewis Arundel; Or, The Railroad Of Life
author: Smedley, Frank E. (Frank Edward), 1818-1864; Browne, Hablot Knight, 1815-1882 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: At ½ past 2 came Mr. Westall till ½ past 3. At 20 minutes to 3 I sat to Mr. Wyon[79] to have my profile taken for a medal, till
quoteLast: . At 6 we dined. Sir John dined here. At a ¼ past 7 we went with Lady Conroy and Lehzen, as usual, to the Opera.
title: The girlhood of Queen Victoria, vol. 1 (of 2)
author: Victoria, Queen of Great Britain, 1819-1901; Esher, Reginald Baliol Brett, Viscount, 1852-1930 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The first onrush was magnificent. Starting at
quoteLast: in the morning, the Allies were within sight of Soissons at ten o'clock, having overrun the whole plateau on a front of some ten kilometres. Rarely has a more successful attack been seen in this war.
title:
World's War Events $v Volume 3
Beginning with the departure of the first American destroyers for service abroad in April, 1917, and closing with the treaties of peace in 1919.
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873-1940 [Editor]

quoteFirst: At half past four our course was south-east and by south; we passed two islands to the south-east of us, at two miles, and a smaller, west south-west a quarter of a mile distant. From this to the Main will be about five miles, or something more. At
quoteLast: , came up to an island which reached to Konfodah. We saw to the west, and west south-west of us, different small islands, not more than half a mile distant.
title:
Travels to Discover the Source of the Nile, Volume 1 (of 5)
In the years 1768, 1769, 1770, 1771, 1772 and 1773
author: Bruce, James, 1730-1794

quoteFirst: The lethargy of afternoon held the thoroughfare in its grip. Occasionally a tradesman’s cart would rattle round the corner, and from time to time cats appeared, stalking purposefully among the evergreens. But at
quoteLast: a girl ran up the steps of Number Eighteen and rang the bell.

quoteFirst: We went on with the game, scorin' wery slow. At
quoteLast: we wos "140 all," neck and neck. Maxwell looked up at the clock.
title: The Betrayal of John Fordham
author: Farjeon, B. L. (Benjamin Leopold), 1833-1903
